The following parts of the contract related to "Parties" should be reviewed by a lawyer:

* Section 22(b) Assignment: This section discusses the assignment of the contract, which may have significant implications for the parties involved. A lawyer should review this section to ensure that the parties understand their rights and obligations regarding assignment.
* Section 22(c) Notice: This section outlines the procedures for giving notice to the parties, which is an important aspect of contract law. A lawyer should review this section to ensure that the parties understand how to provide effective notice.
* Section 22(d) No Agency: This section clarifies that the parties are independent contractors and not partners or agents of each other. A lawyer should review this section to ensure that the parties understand their relationship and obligations.
* Section 22(e) Audit Rights: This section grants the parties the right to inspect each other's records and books of account. A lawyer should review this section to ensure that the parties understand their rights and obligations regarding audits.
* Section 22(f) Force Majeure: This section excuses the parties from performance if certain events occur beyond their control. A lawyer should review this section to ensure that the parties understand their obligations and limitations in the event of a force majeure.

results.question: Highlight the parts (if any) of this contract related to "Insurance" that should be reviewed by a lawyer. Details: Is there a requirement for insurance that must be maintained by one party for the benefit of the counterparty?
results.answer:
Yes, there are several parts related to "Insurance" that should be reviewed by a lawyer:

1. Section 14.I. "INSURANCE." This section requires Franchisee to maintain at Franchisee's expense, in form, amounts and with insurers satisfactory to Pretzel Time, insurance against all types of public liability with personal injury coverage and property damage coverage.
2. Section 14.I. "INSURANCE." This section also requires Franchisee to maintain insurance that includes coverages as set forth in the Operations Manual and contains a provision obligating all insurers to provide a written notice to Pretzel Time of any cancellation or modification of coverage at least thirty (30) days prior to the effective date of such modification or cancellation.
3. Section 14.I. "INSURANCE." This section states that the insurance afforded by the policy or policies respecting liability shall not be limited in any way by reason of any insurance which may be maintained by Pretzel Time.
4. Section 20.H. "PRETZEL TIME'S RIGHT TO PURCHASE ASSETS OF THE UNIT." This section mentions that Franchisee shall maintain in force all insurance policies required for the Unit until the date of closing.

A lawyer should review these sections to ensure that the insurance requirements

results.answer:
Section 13.5 Liquidated Damages states:

"Customer acknowledges that M&I shall suffer a material adverse impact on its business if this Agreement is terminated pursuant to Sections 11.1 or 11.2(A) and that the resulting damages may not be susceptible of precise determination.  Customer acknowledges that the Termination for Convenience Fee and the Termination for Cause Fee are each a reasonable approximation of such damages and shall be deemed to be liquidated damages and not a penalty."

This clause suggests that the contract contains a provision for liquidated damages, specifically the Termination for Convenience Fee and the Termination for Cause Fee, which are deemed to be reasonable approximations of the damages that M&I may suffer in the event of termination. 

However, the contract also states that these fees are not penalties, but rather a reasonable approximation of the damages that M&I may suffer. This suggests that the parties have attempted to negotiate a mutually agreeable amount for liquidated damages, rather than leaving the amount to be determined by a court.

Therefore, it is recommended that a lawyer review this clause to ensure that it is fair and reasonable, and that it complies with any applicable laws or regulations regarding liquidated damages.

Calm shall have thirty (30) business days (the "ROFR Period") from receipt of a ROFR Notice to exercise its ROFR with respect to the region and/or Stores described in the ROFR Notice. 9.3 Successors and Assigns: This section states that a Party may transfer or assign its rights under this IP Agreement in connection with a merger, acquisition or sale of all or substantially all of its assets, on condition that it provides the other Party with notice of the transfer or assignment. Any attempted transfer in contravention of this Section 9.3 shall be null and void.

Additionally, Section 3.3 No Implied License or Other Assignment states that "Except as expressly set out in this IP Agreement and the Asset Purchase Agreement, neither party grants to the other Party, and each Party acknowledges and agrees that the other Party has not granted to it, any other license explicitly or implicitly under any Intellectual Property nor has either party made any transfer or assignment to the other Party of any Intellectual Property or intellectual property rights."

However, Section 9.3 Successors and Assigns also states that "Notwithstanding the foregoing, a Party may transfer or assign its rights under this IP Agreement in connection with a merger, acquisition or sale of all or substantially all of its assets, on condition that it provides the other Party with notice of the transfer or assignment." This suggests that consent or notice may be required from the other party if the contract is assigned to a third party

14.      ASSIGNMENT.

         a)       Assignment. Neither party may assign this Agreement, in whole
                  or in part, without the other party's written consent (which
                  will not be unreasonably withheld), except that no such
                  consent will be required in connection with (i) a merger,

The parts related to "Anti-Assignment" that should be reviewed by a lawyer are:

*   The requirement for written consent from the other party before assigning the contract in whole or in part (Section 14(a)).
*   The exceptions to this requirement, including mergers, reorganizations, or sales of assets, and assignments to wholly-owned subsidiaries or joint ventures (Section 14(a)).
*   The provision that any attempt to assign the contract other than as permitted will be null and void (Section 14(a)).

CONTENT LICENSE AGREEMENT

This Content License Agreement (this "Agreement") is dated as of October 1, 2005 (the "Effective Date") and is by and between Emdeon Corporation a Delaware corporation ("Emdeon"), with offices at at 669 River Drive, Center 2, Elmwood Park, New Jersey 07407 and WebMD, Inc. a Georgia Corporation ("WebMD"), with offices at 111 Eighth Avenue, New York, NY 10011. Emdeon and WebMD expressly agree that this Agreement incorporates the Terms and Conditions attached hereto.

WebMD agrees to grant, and Emdeon agrees to accept, a license to use the Content (as defined below) in connection with various software products it has all right title and interest to (the "Software") in accordance with the terms of this Agreement.

Content to be provided under this Agreement is specified on Exhibit A (the "Content").

Expiration Date: August 31, 2006

AGREED TO AND ACCEPTED:               WebMD, Inc.   Emdeon Corporation               By:     By:

              Name:
results.answer:
The contract contains a license granted by WebMD to Emdeon. Specifically, Section 1(b) states:

"Subject to Emdeon's compliance with the provisions of this Agreement, Emdeon is hereby authorized and licensed to use the Content by making such Content available to third parties verbatim or as source material via the Software."

This section should be reviewed by a lawyer to ensure that the terms and conditions of the license are clear and comply with applicable laws.

Additionally, Section 2(a) describes the Content to be provided by WebMD, and Section 2(b) grants Emdeon a non-exclusive, non-transferable, and worldwide license to use the Content.

The following parts of the contract related to "License Grant" should be reviewed by a lawyer:

* Section 1(b): License grant to Emdeon
* Section 2(a): Description of Content to be provided by WebMD
* Section 2(b): Grant of non-exclusive, non-transferable, and worldwide license to Emdeon

17.5 Assignment; Binding Effect.

(a) Except as otherwise provided in this Section 17.5, neither Party shall assign this Agreement or any rights, benefits or obligations under or relating to this Agreement, in each case whether by operation of law or otherwise, without the other Party's prior written consent (not to be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed).

Section 8. Insurance (entire section) and specifically subsections (a), (b), and (c) should be reviewed by a lawyer. 

Section 8 outlines the insurance requirements for Racing, including types of insurance coverage, limits, and the need for Racing to provide certificates of insurance to the Sponsor. Subsections (a), (b), and (c) detail the specific requirements for Racing to obtain and maintain various types of insurance coverage, including liability insurance, commercial general liability insurance, and workers' compensation insurance. 

A lawyer should review these sections to ensure that the insurance requirements are clear, enforceable, and compliant with applicable laws and regulations.

The following parts of the contract related to "Exclusivity" should be reviewed by a lawyer:

* Section 2.1(c) states that Array grants Ono an exclusive license to Commercialize the Products in the Field in the Ono Territory.
* Section 2.2(a) states that Ono shall have the right to grant sublicenses under the Array Patents and Array Know-How to its Affiliates and to Third Parties, but only with Array's prior written consent.
* Section 2.2(b) states that Ono shall ensure that each of its Sublicensees and distributors is bound by a written agreement that does not conflict with, and contains provisions as protective of the Products and Array, as this Agreement.
* Section 2.3(a) states that if Ono acquires rights from a Third Party that are to be licensed to Array, then the licenses granted to Array shall be subject to Ono's agreeing to promptly reimburse and promptly reimbursing Array for any milestone payments, royalties or other amounts that become owing to such Third Party.

The contract contains several clauses related to liquidated damages and termination fees that should be reviewed by a lawyer. 

1. Section 8.4: Termination Fee Schedule - This section outlines the calculation of a termination fee that Customer must pay to Metavante in the event of termination of the contract for convenience. The fee is calculated based on the Estimated Remaining Value, which is a mathematical product of the average monthly fee paid by Customer and the number of unexpired whole months remaining between the Effective Date of Termination and the expiration of the Initial Term.

2. Section 9.6: Liquidated Damages - This section states that the Termination Fee is a reasonable approximation of the damages that Metavante would suffer as a result of the termination of the contract and is deemed to be liquidated damages and not a penalty.

3. Section 8.4: Termination Fee Schedule - This section also outlines the rebate of a portion of the Termination Fee that Customer may receive if they enter into a new exclusive agreement with Metavante within six months following the Effective Date of Termination.

Article 2.2: "Party A irrevocably undertakes that it will make best efforts to assist and endeavor to achieve the exclusive operation of the cooperative business to the extent permitted by laws."

Article 2.3: "Party A irrevocably undertakes that, without Party B's consent, Party A shall not conduct any other business or make any commercial arrangement, including without limitation being engaged in or otherwise participating in any commercial activities and businesses independently or together with any other person or entity, nor shall it carry out any activities that may be competitive with or cause adverse effect to Party B's business."

Section 3.01(a) states that Honeywell grants a non-exclusive, royalty-free, fully-paid, perpetual, sublicenseable (solely to Subsidiaries and suppliers for "have-made" purposes), worldwide license to use and exercise rights under the Honeywell Shared IP to SpinCo and the members of the SpinCo Group.

Section 4.01(a) states that SpinCo grants a non-exclusive, royalty-free, fully-paid, perpetual, sublicenseable (solely to Subsidiaries and suppliers for "have made" purposes), worldwide license to use and exercise rights under the SpinCo Shared IP to Honeywell and the members of the Honeywell Group.

Section 5.01 states that no Party or any member of its Group may assign or grant a license in or to any of its Intellectual Property Rights licensed to the other Party or any member of its Group pursuant to ARTICLE III or ARTICLE IV, unless such assignment or grant is subject to the licenses, covenants and restrictions set forth herein.

Section 5.02 states that nothing contained in this Agreement shall be construed as conferring any rights (including the right to sublicense) by implication, estoppel or otherwise, under any Intellectual Property Rights, other than as expressly granted in this Agreement.

Section 20.1 of the contract states that "Subject to Section 20.2, neither Party shall, nor shall it purport to, assign, license, transfer or change any of its rights or obligations under this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld conditioned or delayed;"

This indicates that consent is required from the other party if a party wishes to assign, license, transfer, or change any of its rights or obligations under the agreement.

Section 20.2 provides an exception for assignment to an Affiliate or a successor by merger, consolidation, sale of stock or other equity interests or the sale of substantially all of the assets of such Party, but still requires consent from the other party.

Section 20.4 provides an exception for a Change of Control, but requires express consent from the other party.

Section 20.1 also states that consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed, which implies that the other party has some discretion in granting or withholding consent.

Therefore, if a party wishes to assign, license, transfer, or change any of its rights or obligations under the agreement, it should review Section 20.1 and obtain the prior written consent of the other party,

results.answer:
Section 14.8 of the contract states:

"Section 14.8 Assignment. Network Affiliate may not assign or transfer, by operation of law or otherwise, any of its rights under this Agreement or delegate any of its duties under this Agreement to any third party without NCM's prior written consent, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed. For the purposes of this Agreement, any change of control, merger, consolidation, or acquisition of all or substantially all of the assets of Network Affiliate (collectively, a "Change of Control") shall be deemed an assignment. This Agreement shall not be assignable by either party unless the assignee expressly assumes in writing the obligations of the assignor hereunder. Any attempted assignment in violation of this section shall be void."

This section highlights the anti-assignment clause in the contract, which requires Network Affiliate to obtain NCM's prior written consent before assigning or transferring its rights or duties under the agreement to a third party. This includes any change of control, merger, consolidation, or acquisition of Network Affiliate's assets. The section also states that any attempted assignment in violation of this section shall be void.

Section 22(b) of the contract states:

"Assignment. Neither party may assign this Agreement, in whole or in part, without the other party's written consent (which will not be unreasonably withheld), except that no such consent will be required in connection with a merger, reorganization or sale of all, or substantially all, of such party's assets or capital stock. Any attempt to assign this Agreement other than as permitted above will be null and void."

This section indicates that consent or notice is required from the other party if the contract is assigned to a third party, except in the case of a merger, reorganization, or sale of assets.

results.answer: 6. Insurance. HERC shall, throughout the term of this Agreement, obtain and maintain at its own cost and expense, from a qualified AAA-rated insurance company, a standard liability insurance and business interruption policy along with advertising injury protection, all of which must be acceptable to THC and HSI, and which must name THC and HSI as additional insureds. Such policy shall provide, in addition to other protection, protection against any and all claims, demands, and causes of action arising out of any act, omission, negligence or otherwise giving rise to a third party claim. The amount of coverage shall be a minimum of three million dollars ($3,000,000) combined single limit, with no deductible amount for each single occurrence for bodily injury and/or property damage. HERC shall provide for ten (10) days notice to THC and HSI in the event of any modification, cancellation or termination. HERC agrees to furnish THC and HSI Certificates of Insurance evidencing same within thirty (30) days after the execution of this Agreement. In no event shall HERC perform or promote the carry out the activities contemplated under this Agreement or the Trademark, Trade Name, Domain and Related Rights License Agreement prior to receipt by THC and HSI of evidence of insurance.

Astellas shall keep, and require its Affiliates and Sublicensees to keep, complete, true and accurate books of accounts and records for the purpose of determining payments due pursuant to this Agreement. Such books and records shall be kept for at least [ * ] following the end of the calendar quarter to which they pertain. FG shall keep, and require its Sublicensee(s) to keep, complete, true and accurate books of accounts and records for the purpose of verifying the accuracy of the [ * ] Percentage and Fully Burdened Costs. Such records will be open for inspection at the principal place of business of each party (the "Inspected Party") during such [ * ] period by an independent auditor chosen by the other party (the "Inspecting Party") and reasonably acceptable to the Inspected Party for the purpose of verifying the amounts payable by Astellas to FG hereunder or the accuracy of the [ * ] Percentage and/or Fully Burdened Costs. Such inspections may be made no more than once each calendar year, at reasonable times and on reasonable notice. Any books of accounts or records shall not be inspected more than once.
